p: The second technique is to directly extract the driving force information behind the observational data. For example, cross-prediction error 8 and slow feature analysis (SFA) 9 have been successfully applied to extract slowly changing driving forces from non-stationary time series. To evaluate SFA, a modified logistic map has been used to test the ability of SFA to construct the driving forces from an observational time series, and the results showed that there is a good agreement between the constructed and the true driving forces with a correlation coefficient of 0.998 10. This suggests that SFA is suitable for extracting the driving force from observational time series.
